Combat Overview
CombatGroups GroupsCombat Combat is a core part of the game and has its own specific set of rules. Before combat starts all the combatants are divided into groups by the GM, typically there will be be one group of PCs, and one to three groups of monsters/NPCs.
Initiative Order Group Order Malleus Deum uses Group Order to determine the order in which these Groups act during combat. When a Group acts, every member of the group takes a turn. Members of the group may take their turns in any order within their group. So when the PC's group acts, the players may choose the order in which their characters act, within their group, or just take their turns in clockwise order around the table. Once all members of a group have taken their turn, the next group in order acts.
Determining Group Order Before Combat
In mundane combat encounters the GM should just choose the Group Order. If the monsters start the fight then perhaps they should have initiative. Otherwise the GM should consider just allowing the PCs to go first, they are supposed to be the heroes after all. This makes combat faster, keeps the game moving and gives the PCs agency.
If the GM wishes one of a number of different checks may be used before combat to determine group order. These checks are: Initiative, Surprise, and Ambush.
Initiativesubsec:initiative
The GM should consider getting the players to make an initiative check in any of the following circumstances:
The narrative dictates, when confronting "boss" monsters, or
When the stakes are high, when inititiative order might be strategically important to the outome of the combat, or
To punish the PCs for poor strategic decisions, or
To punish the PCs for bad luck when executing their plans.
Initiative Check Initiative is an Opposed Group Delegate check. One member of each group is chosen by the GM to roll an ability check to determine their groups Initiative Result. During combat the groups act in order from highest initiative result to lowest..
An Initiative Check is made using an ability chosen by the GM, and based on context. Some abilities that could be used to make the initiative check are ✱✱perception, ✱✱speed, Listen, and Scout. We use the term Initiative Check to refer to this check irrespective of what underlying ability was used to make the check. Different groups may use different abilities for an Initiative Check.
Surprisesubsec:surprise
sec:surprise Surprise Under certain circumstances it is possible for one group to surprise another group. For this to happen two conditions must be satisfied:
The GM rules that Surprise is possible, and
One group must succeed at a Surprise Check
The GM should rule that surprise is possible when the situation and narrative allow it. For example it may be impossible for one group to surprise another on barren plains where there is no cover for miles around, or when two groups approach each other down a light corridor. The GM should ensure that it is very hard to surprise groups expecting to be attacked.
A Surprise Check is a Group Delegate Check where one character from the surprising group checks their Stealth Result versus one of their opponents Perception or Listen Check Result.
When a group is surprised it gets no actions for the first round of combat. In addition the surprised group must make a Mettle Check. The attackers gain advantage on any Checks during a Surprise Roll. Additionally, whether the surprise attempt is successful or not the would be surpriser automatically wins initiative.
Dourli, attempts to surprise two gang members in the city by attacking them from behind under the cover of darkness. Dourli is aware of his opponents already, but do the gang members become aware of Dourli? Dourli makes a Stealth check against his opponents Perception DC. If successful his opponents will be unaware of him and he will surprise the gang members, if he fails to surprise them he probably should still go first in the initiative, since he is a player character and he initiated the attack.
Ambushsubsec:ambush
Ambush Ambush is special subtype of Surprise that occurs when the ambusher has enough time to plan their initial attack well. For a successful ambush one group must be be stationary waiting in ambush. The other group must move into the ambush area.
Players receive a +6 modifier to their surprise when ambushing, and they receive a -6 modifier to their surprise roll when being ambushed. The effects of being ambushed are the same as those for being surprised. In addition, the ambushers may have had time to set traps and snares, prepare actions, cast non-combat spells at the GMs discretion.
Combat Rounds
Combat rounds represent about ten seconds of time in-game. During a round every member of the combat takes a single Turn.
Actions Standard Action Move Action Minor Action In a characters Turn the character has time to perform a Standard Action, a Move Action and a Minor Action. Actions can be demoted from a Standard Action to a Move or Minor Action, and from a Move Action to a Minor Action. These actions can be performed in any order within a combat round and they are all optional.
There are a few extra complications to combat: Immediate Actions, Reactions, Free Actions, Miscellaneous Actions, and Prepared Actions which we discuss later.
Standard Action
Standard actions are the main combat actions that are used for most physical attacks and many spells. Examples are Sword Strike and Axe Strike.
Move Action
During combat there are a number of different movement actions available. A normal Move Action allows the character to move their normal move distance. A Run Action is performing two Move Actions in a Round, the character Moves and then demotes their Standard Action to another Move Action, moving twice.
The character may Flee which is a Run Action away from danger. Fleeing characters gain an extra d6 movement, but must make a Morale Check to stop fleeing.
Characters may also make a Charge Action. In order to make a charge a character has to be greater than their movement away from the target of their charge. First the charging character moves their movement towards their opponent. Then the Charging character must make a Mettle Check. If they fail, they make an additional move towards their opponent but do not attack. If they succeed they move an additional movement, with a +d6 bonus movement, and may then perform a melee attack.
On a grid, the distance the character may move a number of squares up to the movement value on their character sheet. Using TOTM the GM will dictate distances to the players.
Minor Action
A minor action is any operation that can be performed in very short period of time, grabbing an item from your belt, opening a door, picking an item up .
Free Actions
A Free Action is an optional extra action that the character performs in his turn and that does not count against their limit of actions for their round.
Immediate Actions
Immediate Actions are Free Actions that the characters can perform once, at any time during the round. Examples of Immediate Actions are using Leadership to try and cause a halt to combat to allow negotiation, and Fleeing.
Multi-Turn Actions
Full Turn Action Multi Turn Action Some tasks require longer than a standard action to perform, typically either one or more whole turns. We call these full-turn or multi-turn actions.
A Full Turn Action takes a whole turn to complete. That is one standard action, one move action and one minor action. These actions can be performed in any order and they can be started in one turn and finished in another. Multi Turn Actions require some number of full turn actions. For example, a Two-Turn Action requires two standard actions, two move actions and two minor actions to complete.
Collective Action Collective actions allow multiple characters to contribute actions towards a goal. In these cases all characters that contribute must have the appropriate ability. The character that contributes the last required action rolls for the check. Collective actions should have the collective keyword.
Interuptable Action Long Actions may or may not be interuptable. If an action is interuptable characters can perform some part of the action, then do something else, and the return to the action and continue performing the action without losing previous progress. If an action is not interuptable then any interuption will cause the action to fail and any progress will be lost. Multi-turn actions should be assume not to be interruptable unless otherwise stated.
Reactions
Reactions Under certain circumstances a character will be able to perform an additional Reaction during someone else's action or when a special triggering event occurs.
Reactions are actions that the GM deems may be performed as a Reaction in a given context, or any abilities specially labelled as such, Shield Block, Sword Parry, Cloak Fighting and Dodge. A character may perform at most one reaction per round. If two or more characters want to react to an action the GM decides the reaction order, possibly using an opposed Speed check.
Miscellaneous Actions
Miscellaneous Actions Miscellaneous actions refer to things that characters do during combat for which no explicit rules exist, reading the runes that close a magic portal, releasing a portcullis, mounting a horse, quaffing a potion, pushing a load of barrels over and so on.
For many miscellaneous actions the GM will just have to make a ruling as to the check required and the type of action; standard, move or minor: as it would infeasible for us to provide rules for the myriad of miscellaneous actions that might occur. We suggest that the GM rule that these are minor actions if they can as it encourages strategic thinking and more variety during combat. You could estimate the time required and work out the actions required as follows.. whole turn is 10 seconds, a standard action is six seconds, a move action is three seconds, and a minor action is one second. Then, if an action will take thirty seconds to perform it will need three whole rounds to complete.
Prepared Actions
If the character knows that a combat is imminent they may declare that they prepare an action. At that point, at the GMs discretion, the action gains a +3 check modifier, a prepared arrow shot triggered when someone enters a room would gain a +3 bonus to succeed.
Boons and Banes
CombatBoons CombatBanes Since combat is such a major part of the game the characters will be rolling Boons and Banes quite often. The standard Boon for martial abilities is double damage. The standard Bane for martial abilities is half damage.
Some suggested boons and banes for use during combat checks can be found in Tables table:{{ doc_name }}-defence-fumble and table:{{ doc_name }}-attack-fumble in the appendix.
The thugs have returned to the cellars. Dourli and Roslyn have been unable to escape and now a fight looks inevitable. It's still dark and our heroes have managed to hide from the thugs so far. Dourli attacks the thugs from his hidden position attempting to ambush them. The GM notes that the Thugs will be expecting trouble, they are Alert, and so decides the bonus to ambush the thugs is reduced to +3.
Dourli tries to get advantage from the dark keyword of the cellars and prepares an attack. The GM agrees and gives the adventurers a +1 arguing that the fact that the thugs were expecting to find Dourli down here would somewhat negate that advantage. Dourli agrees.
As this is a group delegate check the GM chooses Roslyn to check her Stealth versus the thugs Perception DC. If Roslyn succeeds then the Thugs are ambushed, Roslyn and Dourli win initiative and get a free round of attacks, the first attack from Dourli gains a bonus to succeed as a prepared action and the thugs must make a morale check.
Dourli and his ally Roslyn, have been cornered by the local gang leader Fenton One-Eye and two of his thugs. A fight in the cellar of the Inn has been underway for some number of rounds. During the fight a few kegs of whisky have been smashed and there is a shallow pool of whisky on the ground.
One of the thugs attacks Dourli with an Axe Strike I. Dourli defends with a Shield Block 3, since he has rank 3 so he rolls 2D12 with a +3 bonus to his block, the attack has a DC of 13 + 1 for the Axe Strike rank. He needs an 11 or more on his roll to succeed. He roll double fours. That is a failure and also a boon. The GM declares that Dourli takes half damage which for an axe is 3 hit points. That has used Dourlis one reaction for the round.
The second thug tries to stab Dourli with his dagger. Dourli has no reactions left so he has to defend with an Armour save.
Movement and Range
Miniatures vs Theatre of the Mind
Movement Miniatures Theatre of the the mind (TOTM) TOTM (Theatre of the the mind) Combat may either be performed on a table with miniatures using a map with a Grid, or purely narratively using the Theatre of the Mind, TOTM.
If the combat takes place on a grid then the map determines the distances for movement, spell area of effect, missile weapon range etc. On a map a run is simply a double movement, a charge is a movement + d6 extra squares then an attack if the enemy is in range. Fleeing characters move twice their movement rate +d6 extra squares.
Movement is halved over difficult terrain. Difficult terrain includes: muddy ground, rocky ground, and generally any terrain with a lot of debris, brambles etc.
Range
Range Long Range Range, Long (-3) Missile weapons and some spells are ranged actions.
Up to that range the action is made without any modifiers. If the ability or weapon has two ranges then the first is the range at which no range modifiers apply. The second range is long range for that ability or weapon and the check suffers a -3 check modifier. If the ability has no second range specified then the ability or weapon cannot be used at a range greater than the one specified and attempts to do so automatically fail.

Cover
Cover Cover provides modifiers to checks for most missile weapons and for melee combat. Light Cover afforded by bushes and the like gives a -3 check modifier, Hard Cover, such as a half wall, provides a -6 check modifier. Full Cover makes hitting the target impossible. The GM should feel free to choose a check modifier that fits the cover available to the characters.
Zones of Control
When playing with TOTM the GM determines whether attacks of opportunity occur. When playing on a grid we need a more precise definition. We define a Zone of Control as the one square perimeter around the character, See Figurefigure:zones. The Ogre A is in character X's zone of control, Ogre B is not.
We suggest you use a scale where the length of one square in the grid corresponds to 2m5'. This value is compatible with other TTRPGs and makes ranged combat sane approximately sane and consistent when converting from metric to imperial or vice versa.

Attacks of Opportunity
If characters or monsters move past opponents during combat they may grant an attack of opportunity which is a standard action made as a reaction to the movement. Disengaging from combat and moving away from combat does not grant an attack of opportunity.
A character grants an Attack of Opportunity every time the they move from one cell in an opponents zone of control into another cell in any opponents zone of control. The attack of opportunity is granted to the opponent whose cell the character moves to. Do not forget the limit of at most one reaction per character per Turn. Reach
Reach Reach weapons, such as spears, are melee weapons with a longer range than most. Weapons with reach have the advantage that they grant an Opportunity Attack when an opponent moves into a characters zone of control. For example, in Figurefigure:reach_weapons, Ogre A gives an attack of opportunity to Character P whenever he moves along the arrows in the diagram if character P is wielding a weapon with the Reach keyword.

Flanking sec:flanking
When playing using theatre of the mind, whether or not a character is flanked is determined by role-playing and GM fiat, the GM might require the character makes a check to leap over a table to get into a flanking position.
When playing on a grid a character is said to be Flanked if he is being attacked by two or more opponents from an angle of greater than 90° degrees. Attacks on flanked characters gain a +3 check modifier, see Figurefigure:flanking

Formation
It is possible to fight in Formation. While fighting in a formation the front row provides hard cover to the back row. The front row must have at least as many people in it as the back row. To make melee attacks from the back row you must be using a weapon with reach. It is possible for a group to have two front rows, to be fighting on two fronts, provided that the number of people in each front row is greater than or equal to the number of people in the back row.

Non-Lethal Combat sec:non-lethal-combat CombatNon-Lethal Combat
There are two categories of combat: Lethal and Non-Lethal. In Non-Lethal combat the participants are not actively trying to kill their opponents, but rather trying to subdue them or drive them off.
There is no difference between Lethal and Non-Lethal combat until an opponents stamina reaches zero and someone becomes Bloodied. At that point a decision has to be made as to whether the combat is lethal or non-lethal. If the combat is non-lethal then the bloodied opponent has to willingly withdraw from the combat or make a morale check to convert the combat to a Lethal Combat. So it is possibly for a non-lethal combat to become lethal at some point during the combat. Ultimately the GM decides what type of combat is occurring, but as a guide combat between civilized humanoids, particularly in places with established legal systems and prohibitions against violence, will be assumed to be non-lethal, at least initially. Combat against monsters and uncivilized humanoids should be considered to be lethal be default.
There is a case where, during a non-lethal combat, a character may have lost most of their stamina, and are then hit with a big hit and lose all their remaining health. In such a case the normal rules for reduction of health to zero apply. This will probably result in either the combat becoming lethal, or the opponents running away. Weapons with the non-lethal keyword reduce the opponents health to one in this case.
Examples of typical non-lethal combat encounters include fights with the local guards, bar-room brawls, fights with gangs of thugs and bandits. There are many reasons to use non-lethal combat: killing people is often a capital crime in human society, there are severe social implications when an individual becomes known as a killer, potentially the players might wish to interrogate an opponent, and bandits might want to make money selling people into slavery.
NPCs and Monsters in Combat sec:npc_combat
NPCs and monsters behave differently from PCs during combat in the following ways:
PCs should automatically win initiative under normal circumstances.
NPC and Monster groups often share a Mettle Pool.
Healing sec:healing
Refreshes SleepHealing RestHealing Healing Characters may heal by taking a long or a short rest. A Short Rest is a ten minute or more length of time that the characters perform no strenuous activity. At the end of a short rest the characters regain all their Stamina and may refresh one dice pool at their dice pool refresh rate.
A Long Rest is a six hour or more length of time that the characters sleep. At the end of a long rest the characters regain all their Stamina, regain Health at their Health Heal rate, and refresh dice into their dice pools at twice their dice pool refresh rate. Previously unused short rests can be taken at the same time as a long rest.
Other Combat Detailssec:combat-details
Counter Attack
Counter Attack counter-attack The character gains an immediate standard melee action as a free action.
Friendly Fire
Friendly Fire friendly-fire The character shooting a ranged weapon into melee strikes an ally in that melee. If there are no allies in the melee the target is involved in, then the attack simply misses. If there are more than one allies in the melee then one ally is targeted randomly. The ally may make a defensive reaction if they have a reaction available.
Abilitiesch:abilities
This chapter describes abilities available to characters in the game. Abilities Each character has a set of Abilities. Abilities may be used in a variety of ways depending on the ability in question. Some abilities allow the player to perform Actions or Ability Checks while others provide the player with passive advantages.
Abilities are keywords and like other keywords, they may be used by the player to gain an advantage in an appropriate context.
Ability Rank Rank - Ability Abilities have ranks. The higher the ability rank the better the character is at that ability and the easier it is for the character to succeed at those ability checks. Ability ranks are written after the ability. So, for example, we might say that Dourli has Axe Cleave 3, which means that he has Axe Cleave at rank 3.
Ability Rank - Untrained Untrained Ability Rank Rank - Untrained Some abilities start with an untrained rank, often 0 or -3. Abilities that have an untrained rank can be attempted without training by any character. All characters automatically have all untrained abilities but we do not usually bother to write these down on the character sheet until they reach rank one.
FIXME UNTRAINED ABILITIES (CHECKS?!) SHOULD ALL BE COMMON!!
Mastering an Ability AbilityMastery You cannot learn an ability unless you have satisfied the prerequisites for that ability. One prerequisite for gaining ability ranks is mastery of the previous rank of the ability. That is, in order to gain rank 2 of an ability, rank 1 must first be mastered. In order to master the ability the player must have successfully used the ability before. All untrained abilities are considered to be automatically mastered already as untrained means the character has no experience in the ability. The first time an unmastered ability is used the character should mark off the success on their character sheet.
When the character goes up a level they gain promotions in certain classes of abilities up to certain ranks. For example a character might gain the following promotions: Martial3, Hammer4, Transport or Craft6. What this means is that the character can raise the rank of any one ability from the Martial section up to a maximum rank of 3 provided that they have satisfied all of that ability ranks prerequisites. The only time prerequisite requirements are waivered is when the text states that the character gains an ability at a given rank.
All abilities have a type. The type of the ability is mainly used to determine when and if an ability can be used during combat. All abilities have one of the following types: reaction, standard, minor, move, immediate, non-combat, keyword. We discuss ability types further in the section on combat.
Default Difficulty Passive Skill DDC (Default Difficulty) SkillDDC SkillPassive SkillDefault Difficulty All abilities have a Default Difficulty, DDC. This is a completely non-binding suggestion to the GM for the difficulty that might be used for checks associated with this skill. Abilities with a DDC of 0 are passive. This means that the the effects of the ability always apply, and that their is no way to successfully make checks with this ability. It follows that there is no way to promote such abilities. Most DDC 0 abilities are reserved for monsters.

Keywords and Conditionsch:keywordsandconditions
Keywords
Keyword A Keyword is a tag, label or signifier attached to something in the game. A cellar might be dark and musty, or a monster's attack might be cold.
Keywords The use of many keywords in game tends to be informal. If the GM describes a cellar as being dark then we say it has the keyword dark. Some keywords are more concretely defined. A dwarven character has the keyword dwarf. Keywords form a bridge between informal narrative gameplay and the formal game rules.
Various rules apply only when certain keywords are in play. Other events apply new keywords to characters, objects and scenarios in the game. Characters may use keywords to gain an advantage in a check. Keywords may also be prerequisites for using abilities, or used to describe weapon damage types, properties that effect magic use, monster classes
Some illustrative examples of keyword use follow:
Damage Types
Damage Types fire, cold, crushing, iron
Racial Categories
Racial Categories dwarf, elf, human, halfling, greenskin
Environmental Descriptions
Environmental Descriptions damp, dark, cold, slimy, smokey, foggy
Dourli hides from a local gang of thugs in a cellar. The GM describes the cellar as dark and dank and storing old barrels. The thugs enter the cellar and look around. Dourli invokes the dark keyword from the GMs description of the cellar saying ``They'll have trouble seeing me in the dark''. The GM agrees and gives Dourli a bonus to his Stealth check.
Common Conditions and Effectssec:conditions
A Condition is a type of keyword that has a well-defined game effect attached to it. All conditions are keywords, but not all keywords are conditions. Conditions represent temporary modifications to things in game, often to characters, Blind, or Dazed.
ConditionSave Ends Save Ends Conditions have different lifetimes. Some conditions typically last for the length of a combat, or until a Save Ends the effects of the condition. Other conditions might be ongoing and terminate at different times. How and when a PC can save to end a condition should be specified on a per condition, or per instance basis. For example text might say: If the character has a fishing net dropped on them they are Prone Agility Save ends with a DC of 12. Saves are made at the end of the characters turn and, if they have multiple saves to make, in any order the character wishes.
The following is a list of some common conditions.
Alert
Alert Condition ConditionsAlert condition:alert The character is alert for danger. They are less likely to be surprised. They gain +2 to Awareness checks. It is difficult to stay alert for long periods of time. PCs cannot claim to be alert for hours on end. Something has to happen to alert them. For example, guards are typically not alert, infiltrators typically are alert. If a group makes a lot of noise, due to combat, then other groups nearby will become alert.
Aware
defn:aware Aware Condition ConditionsAware A character or group is Aware if they believe that they could come into confrontation imminently.
One character or group is Aware of another if they make a successful Perception or Listen check against their opponents Stealth. or if the GM determines they are Aware. If this check fails then the character or group are Unaware. Typically groups will be aware of one another unless one side has approached the other stealthily, or unless one side is laying in ambush. For groups the GM should use a Delegated Group Check. The awareness check can be modified if individuals have the Alert Condition see pagecondition:alert
Black-Powder
Black-Powder KeywordsBlack-Powder keyword:black-powder Black-Powder weapons misfire on a bane.
Blind
Blind Condition ConditionsBlind The character cannot see. Ambush, Surprise, Initiative, Attack Roles, Dodge, Parry and Block receive a -6 modifier against all opponents.
Bloodied
Bloodied Condition ConditionsBloodied The character has suffered damage to their Health. When a character first suffers health damage in a fight they must make a Mettle Check.
Broken
condition:broken Broken Condition ConditionsBroken The character has lost the will to fight and must withdraw from battle. On their turn they may attack but may not move into melee combat unless they have no other choice. This condition occurs after a character has failed two Mettle Checks in combat.
Burning
Burning Condition ConditionsBurning The character is on fire. They must attempt to put out the fire or make a Mettle Check each round to resist doing so.
Checked
condition:checked Checked Condition ConditionsChecked The character has lost momentum in a fight. The character must make a Mettle Check to charge or pursue. This condition occurs after the character has failed a single Mettle Check in combat.
Dazed
Dazed Condition ConditionsDazed The character receives a -2 modifer to all Checks. This often occurs when the character has suffered a nasty injury and are suffering a great deal of pain. Condition lasts for 3 rounds or until a DC 13 Endurance Check is made.
Distracted
Distracted Condition ConditionsDistracted Something has caught the characters attention and they are not paying attention to their surrounds. They make Ambush, Surprise, Missile Attacks, and Perception Checks at -2.
Deaf
Deaf Condition ConditionsDeaf The character cannot hear. They make checks Ambush, Surprise, Perception Checks at -2 and have some trouble communicating with others, use Language Checks to determine success.
Down
Down Condition ConditionsDown Characters who are down are effectively too hurt and too weak to defend themselves or do too much and are in danger of dying. Characters who are Down may make a Mettle Check to make a minor action each turn. Combatants will tend to leave Downed opponents alone until the end of combat when they can be dispatched, eaten, saved for later, ransomed or sold into slavery. Most Down characters also have the Prone condition.
Drunk
Drunk Condition ConditionsDrunk The character has had too much alcohol to drink. They make Agility and Perception checks at -2 and they make Luck Checks at +2. A character that is very drunk makes Agility and Perception checks at -4 and Luck Checks at +2.
Enraged
Enraged Condition ConditionsEnraged The character is wild with rage. They must make a melee attack each round, if they can. If they fail to make a melee attack they are no longer enraged. Otherwise, they must make a Mettle Check to lose this condition.
Exhausted
Exhausted Condition ConditionsExhausted The character is very tired. Make Strength, Endurance, Speed and Movement checks at -2.
Fast
Fast Condition ConditionsFast The NPC forces an Initiative Check when first attacked. The GM should not assume the PCs go first when fighting these characters with the Fast condition.
Fearless
Fearless Condition ConditionsFearless The character has no fear and automatically succeeds any Mettle Checks.
Flanked
Flanked Condition ConditionsFlanked The character is being attacked from multiple sides simultaneously. This drastically reduces their ability to defend themselves and they suffer -2 to their Armour Checks while flanked. See Sectionsec:flanking on pagesec:flanking
Focused
Focused Condition ConditionsFocused The character is well prepared for a ranged attack. +3 to ranged attacks.
Free
Free Condition KeywordsFree Free checks have no point pool cost.
Held
Held/Hold Condition KeywordsHeld/Hold This condition refers to the magical effect, and not to physical restraint. A Held creature may not make melee attacks against the Holder and they may not move closer to the holder at any time while held.
Immune[Damage-Type-Keywords]
Immune[] Condition ConditionsImmune[] The character takes no damage if they are immune to that type of damage. For example, if a character is Immune[Fire] and they take 7 points of damage keyword with Fire then they take no damage.
Immobilized
Immobilized Condition ConditionsImmobilized The character has a great deal of trouble moving. They must make an Agility Check, Speed or Strength check vs DC 13 each round or they cannot move. Whether they succeed or fail, their move distance is reduced by 3.
Invisible
Invisible Condition ConditionsInvisible same as if others were blinded in actions that include the character. Initiative, Attack Roles, Dodge, Parry and Block against this character all receive a -6 modifier.
Maintain
Maintain Keyword KeywordsMaintain keyword:maintain This spell ability requires the character to expend a minor action round to maintain the effect for every subsequent round.
Natural Sprinters
Natural-Sprinter Condition ConditionsNatural-Sprinters While slow to get moving, the character can build up a fair amount of speed in a straight line over time. The character gains +1 move distance while running.
Near-Death
Near-Death Condition ConditionsNear-Death The player must make rolls on the Near-Death table for the character each round until the condition is removed of their character dies. Characters who are Near-Death also have the Down condition and usually will have the Prone condition as well.
Off-Guard
Off-Guard Condition ConditionsOff Guard The character is put off by events around them. All melee combat rolls for the next round are made by the character are made at disadvantage.
Ongoing
Ongoing Keyword KeywordsOngoing keyword:ongoing When a check with the ongoing keyword is successful, the check may be repeated every subsequent round until it fails.
Prone
Prone Condition ConditionsProne The character is on the ground. Performs physical checks at -3. Melee attacks are made against the character with Advantage. Missile attacks are made against the character at Disadvantage. Standing up costs 3 movement.
Pushed[N-Squares]
Pushed Condition ConditionsPushed The character is pushed back N-Squares (N=1 square if not specified). NPCs with Plot-Armour can make a DC 12 Strength Save to avoid the push.
Poisoned
Poisoned Condition ConditionsPoisoned The character is suffering from terrible pain in the stomach or some form of paralysis. They must make a mettle check in order to perform any action.
Resistant[Damage-Type-Keywords]
Resistant[] Condition ConditionsResistant[] The character has all damage decreased by 50 of its normal damage. For example, if a character is Resistant[Fire] and they take 6 points of damage keyword with Fire then they would take an 3 fewer damage. The damage is removed after any boon, bane or other modifier.
Routed
Routed Condition ConditionsRouted The character has been defeated in combat. If they can Flee they do so. Otherwise they will attempt to yield or do something desperate. This occurs when the player has failed three Mettle Checks in combat.
Sick
Sick Condition ConditionsSick The character is feverish and light headed? They perform a mettle check at the start of each turn in combat and if they fail they perform checks that turn at -3.
Slowed
Slowed Condition ConditionsSlowed The character has trouble moving. They must make an Agility Check, Speed or Strength check vs DC 11 each round or their move distance is reduced by 3.
Stunned
Stunned Condition ConditionsStunned The character is stunned and gets one action per round. Lasts one round.
Tired
Tired Condition ConditionsTired The character is tired. Make Strength, Speed and Movement checks at -3.
Unaware
Unaware Condition ConditionsUnaware See the description of Aware in the Surprise section on pagesec:aware. If a character is not Unaware they are Aware.
Unconscious
Unconscious Condition ConditionsUnconscious The character has blacked out or been otherwise incapacitated due to a stunning blow to the head or too much pain. They are not necessarily in immediate danger to their lives. They can perform no actions.
Ungainly
Ungainly Condition ConditionsUngainly creature that has trouble turning and changing direction. must make a move turn in the same direction as the charge straight after making the charge.
Unsteady
Unsteady Condition ConditionsUnsteady The character has been knocked off balance. This condition lasts for one turn. The character defends with disadvantage, and movement is halved.
Vulnerable[Damage-Type-Keywords]
Vunerable[] Condition ConditionsVunerable[] The character has all damage increased by 50 of its normal damage. For example, if a character is Vulernable[Fire] and they take 6 points of damage with the Fire keyword then they would take an extra 3 damage. The extra damage is added after any boon, bane or other modifier.
